question: How do you handle disagreements with your partner over household chores?

choices.A: I ignore the issue and hope it goes away (Avoidance)
choices.B: I do the chores myself to keep the peace (Accommodation)
choices.C: I suggest we split the chores evenly (Compromise)
choices.D: I propose we work together on the chores to make it fun (Collaboration)
choices.E: I insist that my way of doing chores is better (Competition)

question: You and your friend can't decide where to go for dinner. How do you handle it?

choices.A: I let my friend choose the place (Accommodation)
choices.B: I push to go to my favorite spot (Competition)
choices.C: I suggest we go somewhere that has both our favorite dishes (Compromise)
choices.D: I suggest skipping dinner and doing something else (Avoidance)
choices.E: I try to find a place we both enjoy equally (Collaboration)

question: At work, you disagree with a coworker about how to approach a project. How do you respond?

choices.A: I stand my ground and insist on using my approach (Competition)
choices.B: I avoid bringing up my disagreement (Avoidance)
choices.C: I agree with their approach to avoid conflict (Accommodation)
choices.D: I suggest we each incorporate parts of our ideas (Compromise)
choices.E: I propose a meeting to combine the best of both ideas (Collaboration)

question: You and your sibling are fighting over who gets the last piece of cake. What do you do?

choices.A: I insist it's mine because I saw it first (Competition)
choices.B: I offer to share it equally and enjoy it together (Collaboration)
choices.C: I walk away and let them have it (Avoidance)
choices.D: I let them have it to avoid arguing (Accommodation)
choices.E: I suggest we cut it in half (Compromise)

question: How do you deal with a neighbor who plays loud music at night?

choices.A: I suggest a compromise, like lowering the volume after 10 PM (Compromise)
choices.B: I tell them to stop immediately or I’ll report it (Competition)
choices.C: I ignore it and hope they stop (Avoidance)
choices.D: I don't say anything to keep things peaceful (Accommodation)
choices.E: I knock on their door and ask if we can agree on quiet hours (Collaboration)

question: You and your partner disagree on how to spend the weekend. How do you handle it?

choices.A: I go along with their plan to avoid conflict (Accommodation)
choices.B: I suggest splitting the weekend, one day their way and one day my way (Compromise)
choices.C: I propose activities we both enjoy (Collaboration)
choices.D: I avoid discussing plans and just go with the flow (Avoidance)
choices.E: I insist we do what I want because I had plans first (Competition)

question: At a family gathering, a heated political debate breaks out. How do you react?

choices.A: I strongly argue for my point of view (Competition)
choices.B: I suggest everyone agree to disagree (Compromise)
choices.C: I encourage everyone to calmly discuss their views (Collaboration)
choices.D: I stay out of the debate entirely (Avoidance)
choices.E: I agree with whatever side is more peaceful (Accommodation)

question: Your coworker took credit for your work. How do you handle it?

choices.A: I immediately confront them and demand credit (Competition)
choices.B: I talk to them privately and suggest sharing credit (Compromise)
choices.C: I approach them to discuss how we can both get recognition (Collaboration)
choices.D: I avoid bringing it up and move on (Avoidance)
choices.E: I let it slide to avoid making a scene (Accommodation)

question: Your partner wants to watch a movie you don’t like. What do you do?

choices.A: I propose taking turns picking movies (Collaboration)
choices.B: I suggest watching something we both enjoy (Compromise)
choices.C: I insist we watch what I like because I picked last time (Competition)
choices.D: I let them watch it while I do something else (Avoidance)
choices.E: I agree to watch it to make them happy (Accommodation)

question: Your friend asks for help moving, but you have other plans. How do you handle it?

choices.A: I suggest helping them another day (Compromise)
choices.B: I offer to help for a few hours but keep my plans afterward (Collaboration)
choices.C: I tell them I can’t help and stick to my plans (Competition)
choices.D: I avoid the conversation altogether (Avoidance)
choices.E: I cancel my plans to help them move (Accommodation)

question: During a group project, a team member isn’t pulling their weight. What do you do?

choices.A: I do extra work to cover for them (Accommodation)
choices.B: I suggest splitting the work more evenly (Compromise)
choices.C: I ignore the issue and hope it improves (Avoidance)
choices.D: I tell the group we need to replace them or I’ll take over (Competition)
choices.E: I talk to them about how we can all contribute equally (Collaboration)

question: You and your partner have different opinions about how to decorate the house. What do you do?

choices.A: I let them decorate as they please (Accommodation)
choices.B: I suggest we each decorate our own areas (Compromise)
choices.C: I propose finding a style we both like (Collaboration)
choices.D: I avoid discussing it (Avoidance)
choices.E: I insist on decorating the way I want (Competition)

question: Your friend and you disagree on where to go on vacation. How do you handle it?

choices.A: I suggest splitting the trip into two destinations (Compromise)
choices.B: I go with their choice to keep the peace (Accommodation)
choices.C: I insist on my choice because I planned the trip (Competition)
choices.D: I try to find a vacation spot we both enjoy (Collaboration)
choices.E: I let them decide and stay out of it (Avoidance)

question: You and your coworker clash on a project deadline. How do you respond?

choices.A: I insist on sticking to the original deadline (Competition)
choices.B: I suggest a reasonable extension to meet halfway (Compromise)
choices.C: I talk to my coworker and suggest a fairer solution (Collaboration)
choices.D: I avoid confronting them and let the deadline slide (Avoidance)
choices.E: I agree to extend the deadline to avoid issues (Accommodation)

question: You and your partner are arguing over finances. What do you do?

choices.A: I insist on managing the finances my way (Competition)
choices.B: I suggest we compromise by budgeting for both our needs (Compromise)
choices.C: I propose sitting down and planning a budget together (Collaboration)
choices.D: I avoid talking about money to keep the peace (Avoidance)
choices.E: I agree to follow their financial plan (Accommodation)

question: A friend is upset because you were late to meet them. How do you handle it?

choices.A: I apologize and take all the blame (Accommodation)
choices.B: I suggest we meet in the middle to avoid future delays (Compromise)
choices.C: I talk it through and find a way to prevent it next time (Collaboration)
choices.D: I defend my reasons for being late (Competition)
choices.E: I avoid bringing it up and hope they forget (Avoidance)

question: Your boss gives you a task you feel is unfair. How do you react?

choices.A: I tell my boss it's not part of my job and refuse (Competition)
choices.B: I suggest a compromise, like sharing the task with others (Compromise)
choices.C: I talk to my boss and suggest a fairer solution (Collaboration)
choices.D: I don’t say anything and just do it (Avoidance)
choices.E: I accept the task to avoid conflict (Accommodation)

question: During a heated discussion, how do you handle conflict?

choices.A: I push my point until the other person agrees (Competition)
choices.B: I suggest we both give a little to resolve it (Compromise)
choices.C: I try to discuss the issue calmly and find a solution (Collaboration)
choices.D: I avoid saying anything to calm things down (Avoidance)
choices.E: I agree with the other person to end the argument (Accommodation)

question: How do you deal with a friend who is consistently late?

choices.A: I avoid bringing it up and just deal with it (Avoidance)
choices.B: I suggest meeting them halfway in timing (Compromise)
choices.C: I talk to them about why punctuality matters to me (Collaboration)
choices.D: I insist that they need to be on time or I’ll stop meeting them (Competition)
choices.E: I let it go every time to avoid confrontation (Accommodation)

question: You and your roommate disagree on how to split household bills. How do you solve it?

choices.A: I suggest we each pay for what we use (Compromise)
choices.B: I avoid talking about finances to keep the peace (Avoidance)
choices.C: I let them decide how we split the bills (Accommodation)
choices.D: I propose working together to find a fair split (Collaboration)
choices.E: I insist on paying only my share (Competition)

question: You and your partner argue over where to spend the holidays. How do you resolve it?

choices.A: I agree to go wherever they want (Accommodation)
choices.B: I insist on going to my family’s place (Competition)
choices.C: I avoid talking about it and hope it works itself out (Avoidance)
choices.D: I suggest splitting the time between both families (Compromise)
choices.E: I try to find a plan that makes both of us happy (Collaboration)

question: You and a colleague both want to lead a new project. How do you handle it?

choices.A: I let them take the lead to avoid conflict (Accommodation)
choices.B: I propose we find the best fit based on skills (Collaboration)
choices.C: I insist on leading the project myself (Competition)
choices.D: I step back and let them take the lead (Avoidance)
choices.E: I suggest we co-lead the project (Compromise)

question: A family member keeps borrowing money without returning it. How do you react?

choices.A: I avoid talking about it and just deal with it (Avoidance)
choices.B: I suggest a repayment plan we both agree on (Compromise)
choices.C: I talk to them about how it’s impacting me and find a solution (Collaboration)
choices.D: I let it go to avoid tension in the family (Accommodation)
choices.E: I insist they pay me back immediately (Competition)

question: A colleague disagrees with your approach to a task. How do you respond?

choices.A: I agree with them to keep things smooth (Accommodation)
choices.B: I avoid discussing it and just go with their idea (Avoidance)
choices.C: I suggest meeting in the middle with our ideas (Compromise)
choices.D: I talk to them to find a mutually beneficial approach (Collaboration)
choices.E: I insist on doing it my way (Competition)

question: Your friend borrowed your favorite jacket without asking. What do you do?

choices.A: I avoid confronting them about it (Avoidance)
choices.B: I demand they return it immediately (Competition)
choices.C: I let it go and say nothing to keep the peace (Accommodation)
choices.D: I suggest that they ask next time and I’ll lend it (Compromise)
choices.E: I talk to them about why it’s important to ask first (Collaboration)
